_header: When life is most loved and death is most hated
Note: For other MSS that lack this couplet see 1170.
Bibliographic Ghosts: San Marino, CA, Henry Huntington Library HM 144 [olim Huth 7] , f. 13v: actually in San Marino, CA, Henry Huntington Library HM 744 [olim Ashburnham 133; olim Gollancz].
_description: ‘Erthe upon Erthe’ (B version) — in quatrains, with an introductory couplet

Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964.

BodRawPoe32.First Lines: Whanne life is most louydAnd deth is most hatid…
BodRawPoe32.Last Lines:
…So that erthe for the ertheStyd vp to thi holy
                    hille
BodRawPoe32.Editions:
Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964. 
Fiedler,  H. G. 
             “Earth upon Earth.” 
             Modern Language Review
         3 (1908): 218-27: 222.

CamStJohn127.First Lines:
Whan lyf is louyd & deþ ys most hatidDeþ drawiþ
                    his drawȝtis & maket man ful nakid…
CamStJohn127.Last Lines:
…Wyte erþe uppon erþe þat owre ne be for
                    loreAnd brynge owre erþe þer boote is þer fore
CamStJohn127.Note:
Immediately follows Edmund Rich’s Speculum Ecclesie, 14
                    monorhyming quatrains with introductory couplet.
CamStJohn127.Editions:
Förster,  Max. 
             “Die älteste Fassung des mittelenglishce Gedichtes Earth Upon
                Earth.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         138 (1919): 39-61: 50.
Pope,  Nancy. 
             “Erthe upon Erthe Revisited.” 
             Journal of the Early Book Society
         21 (2018): 53-95: 80-3.

BLAdd37788.First Lines:
Whanne lyf is moost loued & deeþ is moost hatedþanne
                    deeþ drawet his drauȝt & makiþ man ful
                    nakid…
BLAdd37788.Last Lines:
…but þat þis erþe in þis erþe be worching
                    þi willeso þat erþe fro þis erþe stiȝ up to
                    þin hiȝ hille
BLAdd37788.Note:
Written as prose. “This copy of ‘Erthe’ begins with the introductory couplet, but Babington (1860)
XBabington,  Churchill. 
             The Repressor of Over Much Blaming of the Clergy, by Reginald
                Pecock.
             2 vols. 
             Rolls Series
         19 (1860; repr. Kraus, 1966)’s work on Tenison’s manuscript (1.lxxii, n.) assigned the couplet to the end of the preceding item rather than to the beginning of ‘Erthe,’ thereby causing confusion in all the Middle English verse indices to date” (Nancy Pope, personal communication February 27, 2017).
BLAdd37788.Editions:
Pope,  Nancy. 
             “Erthe upon Erthe Revisited.” 
             Journal of the Early Book Society
         21 (2018): 53-95: 72-4 (see note 18, p. 75).

BLEge1995.First Lines:
Whenne lyfe ys moste louyde and dethe ys moste hatydeDethe drawythe
                    hys draught and makythe man nakyde…
BLEge1995.Last Lines:
…And pray to god a pon erthe that alle the erthe hath
                    wroughtThat erthe owte of the erthe to blys may be brought
BLEge1995.Editions:
Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964.

BLHar1671.First Lines: Wanne lyf is moste louydAnd dethe ys most hatyd…
BLHar1671.Last Lines:
…And y pray to god Apon erth that all erth hath wroughtThat
                    erth out of erth to blysse may be brought
BLHar1671.Note:
First four lines are added in the margin by a different
                    hand.
BLHar1671.Editions:
Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964.

BLHar4486.First Lines:
When lyffe is most loued & deth is moste hatedThen dethe
                    draweth his drawght & makyth man full naked…
BLHar4486.Last Lines:
…But that this erthe in this erthe be euer worshyng thy
                    wylleSo that this erthe fro þis erthe may stie vp to thy
                    hille
BLHar4486.Editions:
Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964.

NLS19111.Note: 3 lines only, repeated on the same folio. The introductory couplet also occurs on fol. 70r (Nancy Pope, personal communication, February 27, 2017).
NLS19111.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild. 
             A Register of Middle English Religious & Didactic Verse.
         2 vols. London: Oxford University Press for the Bibliographical
            Society: 1916-20: 1.505.

Lam223.Transcription:
Where lyffe ys most lofyt & dethe ys most hatytThen dravste hys
                    dreght & makys mon fall nakyt
Lam223.Attributed Author:
quod Petrus Raynstroft (f. 296, in the same hand as these lines which is
                    different and later than the hand of the Legenda Aurea).
Lam223.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild. 
             A Register of Middle English Religious & Didactic Verse.
         2 vols. London: Oxford University Press for the Bibliographical
            Society: 1916-20: 1.363.
 Bad Key: James1930-3: 363.

Lam853.First Lines:
ERþe out of erþe is wondirly wrouȝtErþe of
                    erþe haþ gete a dignyte of nouȝt…
Lam853.Last Lines:
…But þat þis erþe on þis erþe be euere
                    worchinge þi willeSo þat þis erþe from þis
                    erþe may stie up to þin hiȝ hille AMEN
Lam853.Attributed Title:
Whanne liif is moost loued and deeþ is moost hatid þanne
                    dooþ deeþ drawe his drawȝt and makiþ man ful nakid De terra
                    plasmasti me & cetera (p. 35, rubric)

Wellcome673.First Lines:
When lyfe is moost louedAnd deþe is moost hatedThen
                    deþe drawiþ his drauȝtAnd makiþ men
                    naked…
Wellcome673.Last Lines:
…And pray to god vpon erþe þat all haþ made of
                    nouȝtÞat erþe out of erþe to blysse may be
                    brouȝt

Formerly listed under 1171; moved as per Louis (1992)

HunHM744.First Lines:
Whan liif is most loued and deeþ most hatid[þ]anne
                    deeþ drawid his drauȝt and makiþ man ful nakidErde out of
                    erþe is wondirly wrouȝtErþe of erde haþe gete a dignite
                    of nouȝt…
HunHM744.Last Lines:
…but þat þis erþe in þis erþe be euer
                    worchinge þi willeso þat erþe fro þis erþe may
                    stiȝe up to þin hiȝ hille
HunHM744.Note:
Written as prose; wrongly listed as in San Marino, CA,  Henry Huntington Library HM 144 [olim Huth 7] in Brown  and  Robbins (1943)
